title: How to make your writing suspenseful - Victoria Smith

multiple-choice.question: What makes a good horror story, according to H.P. Lovecraft?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of monsters and blood

options.label: B
options.text: The use of suspense and the unknown

options.label: C
options.text: The setting of a haunted mansion

options.label: D
options.text: The character of a serial killer

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to suspense in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: Setting up a question and delaying the answer

options.label: B
options.text: Revealing all the answers at once

multiple-choice.question: What is a technique used to achieve suspense in writing?
What is an example of a setting that suggests disturbing things are being concealed?

options.label: A
options.text: A sunny day in a park

options.label: B
options.text: An old mansion with winding halls and secret passageways

multiple-choice.question: Who is known for using extended silences and shots of staircases to create a feeling of discomfort in his cinematography?
What is the technique known as dramatic irony?

options.label: A
options.text: When the audience knows more than the characters

options.label: B
options.text: When the characters know more than the audience

options.label: C
options.text: When the setting is used to create suspense

options.label: D
options.text: When the villain is revealed early on

multiple-choice.question: What is the cliffhanger?

options.label: A
options.text: A technique used to create suspense by revealing key parts of the big secret to the audience

options.label: B
options.text: A technique used to create suspense by delaying the answer to a question

options.label: C
options.text: A technique used to create suspense by revealing the villain early on

options.label: D
options.text: A technique used to create suspense by cutting off a chapter or episode right before something crucial is revealed

title: Why should you read James Joyce's "Ulysses"? - Sam Slote

multiple-choice.question: What is James Joyce's novel "Ulysses" widely considered to be?

options.label: A
options.text: A literary masterpiece and one of the easiest works of literature to read.

options.label: B
options.text: A literary masterpiece and one of the hardest works of literature to read.

options.label: C
options.text: A novel about the life of James Joyce.

options.label: D
options.text: A novel about the city of Dublin.

multiple-choice.question: What is the plot of "Ulysses" based on?

options.label: C
options.text: The story of three characters: Stephen Dedalus, Leopold Bloom, and Bloom's wife Molly.

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about the way each chapter of "Ulysses" is written?

options.label: A
options.text: Each chapter is written in a different style.

options.label: B
options.text: Each chapter is written in the same style.

options.label: C
options.text: Each chapter is written in a style that is different from the previous one.

options.label: D
options.text: Each chapter is written in a style that is the same as the previous one.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the literary references in "Ulysses"?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the novel more difficult to read.

options.label: B
options.text: To make the novel more interesting.

options.label: C
options.text: To add depth and complexity to the novel.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the title "Ulysses"?

options.label: A
options.text: It refers to the main character of the novel.

options.label: B
options.text: It refers to the city of Dublin.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a random title chosen by James Joyce.

multiple-choice.question: Why was "Ulysses" put on trial, banned, and censored in the U.S.?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was considered too difficult to read.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was considered too easy to read.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it contained too many references to sex and other mature themes.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was not considered a "great" novel.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the setting of "Ulysses"?

options.label: B
options.text: It is a real city that is accurately depicted.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a city that is not important to the plot of the novel.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a city that is not relevant to the themes of the novel.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between James Joyce and the city of Dublin?

options.label: A
options.text: He was born and raised in Dublin.

options.label: B
options.text: He lived outside of Dublin while writing "Ulysses".

options.label: D
options.text: He was not interested in Dublin.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the statement "If 'Ulysses' isn't worth reading, then life isn't worth living"?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a statement about the importance of reading.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a statement about the difficulty of reading.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a statement about the value of life.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a statement about the author's intentions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the tone of "Ulysses"?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a serious and somber novel.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a humorous and lighthearted novel.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a complex and nuanced, with both serious and humorous elements.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a novel that is neither serious nor humorous.

title: What in the world is topological quantum matter? - Fan Zhang

multiple-choice.question: What technology could be built if electricity could travel forever without being diminished, and a computer could run exponentially faster with perfect accuracy?

options.label: D
options.text: A device that converts electricity to heat.

multiple-choice.question: What is a branch of mathematics that focuses on fundamental properties of objects, and doesn't change when an object is gradually stretched or bent?
What type of material conducts electricity around the edge but not in the middle?
What type of computer takes advantage of the fact that subatomic particles can be in different states at the same time to store information in something called qubits?
What is a type of qubit that is protected from being changed by small or local disturbances?
Who won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 2016 for discovering that even microscopic matter at the smallest scale can exhibit macroscopic properties and phases that are topological?

options.label: A
options.text: David Thouless, Duncan Haldane, and Michael Kosterlitz.

options.label: B
options.text: Albert Einstein, Niels Bohr, and Max Planck.

options.label: C
options.text: Stephen Hawking, Roger Penrose, and Frank Wilczek.

options.label: D
options.text: Richard Feynman, Murray Gell-Mann, and Julian Schwinger.

multiple-choice.question: What is a type of exotic phase of matter that is stable and has remarkable characteristics?
What is a type of property that doesn't change when an object is gradually stretched or bent?
What is a type of object that has one hole, and can be reshaped into a coffee cup without changing its topological property?
What is a type of object that has three holes, and cannot be turned into a donut without tearing two new holes?

multiple-choice.question: Who was the Roman poet who died on his journey back to Italy in 19 B.C.?

options.label: C
options.text: Because he was interested in saving Virgil's legacy

options.text: Because he wanted to rival the Greek epics

options.label: B
options.text: The first six books echo the Iliad, and the last six mirror the Odyssey

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What is the meter in which the Aeneid is written?

options.label: A
options.text: Aeneas, a reluctant hero who struggles with his duty and often seems a reluctant leader

options.label: B
options.text: Aeneas, a model for Augustus who is hailed as a victor entering Rome in triumph

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: It is a symbol of the arrival of permanent peace in Rome

options.label: B
options.text: It is a symbol of the departure of peace from Rome

options.label: C
options.text: It is a symbol of the power of the Roman Empire

options.label: D
options.text: It is a symbol of the greatness of Augustus

multiple-choice.question: Why did Virgil present Augustus as a victor entering Rome in triumph?

options.label: B
options.text: To present Augustus as a model for the Roman people

options.label: C
options.text: To show the greatness of Rome

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Aeneid in the context of Roman politics in the second half of the 1st century B.C.?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a celebration of the Roman Empire

options.label: B
options.text: It is a critique of the Roman Republic

options.label: C
options.text: It is a presentation of the great sacrifices that the Romans had endured

options.label: D
options.text: It is a presentation of the unsettled nature of Roman politics

multiple-choice.question: Why did Virgil want the story of the Aeneid published?

options.label: B
options.text: To present Augustus as a model for the Roman people

options.label: C
options.text: To give the Romans a fresh sense of their origins, their past, and their potential

title: How did Polynesian wayfinders navigate the Pacific Ocean? - Alan Tamayose and Shantell De Silva

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To memorize the rising and setting points of stars and constellations

options.label: D
options.text: To use mental tricks to estimate where south is

options.label: C

title: Why is it so hard to cure cancer? - Kyuson Yun

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to cure cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Because cancer is a single disease with a single cause.

options.label: B
options.text: Because cancer arises from normal cells accumulating mutations.

options.label: C
options.text: Because cancer is a simple disease that can be treated with a single medicine.

options.label: D
options.text: Because cancer is a disease that only affects old people.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in developing new cancer treatments?

options.label: A
options.text: Finding new ways to study cancer.

options.label: B
options.text: Understanding the genetic mutations that cause cancer.

options.label: C
options.text: Developing treatments that can target all types of cancer.

options.label: D
options.text: Understanding the complex interactions between cancer cells and healthy cells.

multiple-choice.question: What is clonal heterogeneity in cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of multiple populations of cancerous cells in a single tumor.

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of a single population of cancerous cells in a tumor.

options.label: C
options.text: The absence of cancerous cells in a tumor.

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of healthy cells in a tumor.

multiple-choice.question: What is a cancer stem cell?

options.label: A
options.text: A rare type of cancer cell that is highly susceptible to chemotherapy.

options.label: B
options.text: A rare type of cancer cell that is highly resistant to chemotherapy.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of healthy cell that is found in a tumor.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of cancer cell that is found in a tumor.

multiple-choice.question: Why are cancer cells able to adapt to treatments?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are able to change their molecular and cellular characteristics.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are able to communicate with healthy cells.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are able to form blood vessels that feed the tumor.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are able to suppress the immune system.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of cancer research?

options.label: A
options.text: To understand the causes of cancer.

options.label: B
options.text: To develop new treatments for cancer.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the interactions between cancer cells and healthy cells.

multiple-choice.question: What is the average mortality rate for most kinds of cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: It has increased significantly since the 1970s.

options.label: B
options.text: It has decreased significantly since the 1970s.

options.label: C
options.text: It has remained the same since the 1970s.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in treating aggressive brain tumors?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of multiple populations of cancerous cells.

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of healthy cells in the tumor.

options.label: C
options.text: The absence of cancerous cells in the tumor.

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of cancer stem cells.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the immune system in cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: To recognize and destroy cancer cells.

options.label: B
options.text: To suppress the function of cancer cells that recognize cancer cells.

options.label: C
options.text: To communicate with cancer cells and form blood vessels.

options.label: D
options.text: To change the molecular and cellular characteristics of cancer cells.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main challenge in developing new cancer treatments that can target cancer stem cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Understanding the interactions between cancer cells and healthy cells.

options.label: B
options.text: Understanding the genetic mutations that cause cancer.

options.label: C
options.text: Developing treatments that can target all types of cancer.

options.label: D
options.text: Figuring out how to target cancer stem cells.

multiple-choice.question: What can potentially outlast physical limitations such as decomposition and degradation of hard drives?

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Adenine, Guanine, Cytosine, and Amine (A, G, C, and A)

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: Enough to store 10 billion HD movies on a single DVD

options.label: D

title: A young inventor's plan to recycle Styrofoam

options.label: C

options.label: A
options.text: To filter out contaminants from water or air.

options.text: To stop working on the project.

options.label: B
options.text: To file a patent on their process.

options.label: C
options.text: To continue testing and making the process more effective.

options.label: D
options.text: To share their results with the public.

options.text: The nsta's e-cyber mission stem and action program award.

options.text: That it's okay to give up when things get tough.

options.label: A
options.text: It reduced styrofoam waste and created activated carbon for purifying water.

options.label: D

options.text: A precursor to the medicine known today as aspirin.

options.label: B
options.text: That aspirin is a new type of painkiller.

options.text: That aspirin is a new type of shelter.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It reduces the risk of getting and dying from cancer.

title: Why Facts Don't Convince People (and what you can do about it)

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why humans make decisions based mostly on emotions instead of facts?

options.label: A
options.text: The human brain evolved to help us survive and not necessarily to help us be factually accurate.

options.label: B
options.text: The human brain is not capable of processing complex information.

options.label: D
options.text: The human brain is not designed for decision-making.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when someone's worldview is challenged?

options.label: A
options.text: The same part of the brain that processes physical danger gets activated, causing people to react aggressively.

options.label: B
options.text: People become more open-minded and receptive to new information.

options.label: C
options.text: The person becomes more confident in their beliefs.

options.label: D
options.text: The person becomes less empathetic towards others.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "backfire effect" that happens when people encounter facts that contradict their current beliefs?

options.label: A
options.text: People become more convinced of their original ideas.

options.label: B
options.text: People become less convinced of their original ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: People become more open-minded and receptive to new information.

options.label: D
options.text: People become more aggressive and defensive.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem of lack of empathy that occurs when humans are divided into groups?

options.label: A
options.text: People become more empathetic towards members of other groups.

options.label: B
options.text: People become less empathetic towards members of other groups.

options.label: C
options.text: People become more aggressive and defensive.

options.label: D
options.text: People become more open-minded and receptive to new information.

multiple-choice.question: What can you do to prevent someone's brain from seeing you as a personal threat when presenting factual information that clashes with their beliefs?

options.label: A
options.text: Look for ways to identify the person as part of your tribe and you as part of theirs.

options.label: B
options.text: Ignore the person's feelings and present the facts anyway.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first step in presenting factual information that clashes with someone's beliefs?

options.label: A
options.text: Look for ways to identify the person as part of your tribe and you as part of theirs.

options.label: B
options.text: Present the facts and ignore the person's feelings.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when people are divided into groups of any kind?

options.label: A
options.text: People become more empathetic towards members of other groups.

options.label: B
options.text: People become less empathetic towards members of other groups.

options.label: C
options.text: People become more aggressive and defensive.

options.label: D
options.text: People become more open-minded and receptive to new information.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem of lack of empathy that makes things like slavery and genocide possible in our society?

options.label: A
options.text: The human brain is not capable of processing complex information.

options.label: B
options.text: The human brain is not designed for empathy.

options.label: C
options.text: The humanization of other groups is what makes things like slavery and genocide possible.

options.label: D
options.text: The human brain is not capable of experiencing emotions.

multiple-choice.question: What can you do if you want someone to consider factual information that clashes with their beliefs?

options.label: A
options.text: Look for ways to identify the person as part of your tribe and you as part of theirs.

options.label: B
options.text: Present the facts and ignore the person's feelings.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem that prevents us from having intelligent political debates?

options.label: A
options.text: The human brain is not capable of processing complex information.

options.label: B
options.text: The human brain is not designed for decision-making.

multiple-choice.question: What is smog?

options.text: A type of pollution that affects only urban areas.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of pollution that is formed by smoke and fog.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of pollution that is formed by smoke and chemicals.

options.text: A type of pollution that is formed by the incomplete combustion of gas in motor vehicles.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of pollution that is formed by the reaction of nitrogen oxides and sunlight.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of compound that easily becomes vapor and may contain elements such as carbon, oxygen, hydrogen, chlorine, and sulfur.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of pollution that is formed by the burning of coal.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of smog that is formed by the burning of coal.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of smog that is formed by the reaction of VOCs and nitrogen oxides.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of smog that is formed by the reaction of VOCs and sunlight.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: A type of pollution that is formed by the burning of coal.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of pollution that is formed by the reaction of nitrogen oxides and sunlight.

options.label: D

options.text: To keep the membrane at the right fluidity

options.label: C
options.text: To protect the cell from external substances

options.label: D
options.text: To provide structural support to the cell

multiple-choice.question: What is the process by which the cell membrane fuses two different bilayers?
What would happen if the cell membrane were not present?

options.label: A
options.text: The cell would be able to regulate its internal environment

options.label: B
options.text: The cell would be able to communicate with other cells

options.label: C
options.text: The cell would not be able to function

options.label: D
options.text: The cell would not be able to grow and divide
